revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/64.237.25.230|64.237.25.230]] ([[User talk:64.237.25.230|talk]]) to last revision by Anachronist. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
In [[Rugby league|rugby league football]], the '''Laws of the Game''' are the rules governing how the sport is played.<ref name="ILG-2004-p1">[[#RLIF-ILG-2004|RLIF, 2004]]: 1</ref><ref name="ARL-laws-2009-p1">[[#ARL-laws-2009|ARL, 2009]]: 1</ref> The Laws are the responsibility of the [[Rugby League International Federation]],<ref>[http://www.rlif.com/about_the_rlif/regulations_and_laws The Laws of Rugby League]</ref> and cover the play, officiating, equipment and procedures of the game.
The Laws have undergone significant changes since pioneers of the sport broke away from the [[Rugby football]] establishment in 1895. The sport has been described as a "constantly evolving animal, particularly with professional coaches, [with which] the rules have to keep pace".<ref name="fagan20-11-07">{{Cite web|url=http://www.rl1908.com/blog/rules-fix.htm |title=Evolving animal |last=Fagan |first=Sean |date=2007-11-20 |publisher=rl1908.com |accessdate=7 January 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5masdTO86?url=http://www.rl1908.com/blog/rules-fix.htm |archivedate= 7 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
{{TOC right}}
==Laws== The current ''Laws of the Game'' and ''Notes on the Laws'' are set out in 17 sections:<ref name="ILG-2004-p1"/> * Section  1: [[Rugby league playing field|Playing Field]] * Section  2: [[List of rugby league terms|Glossary]] * Section  3: [[Football (ball)#Rugby football|Ball]] * Section  4: Player and Players' Equipment * Section  5: [[Rugby league gameplay#Mode of play|Mode of Play]] * Section  6: [[Rugby league gameplay#Point scoring|Scoring]] * Section  7: Timekeeping * Section  8: Kick-off and Drop-out * Section  9: Touch and Touch in-Goal * Section 10: Knock-on and Forward Pass * Section 11: [[Rugby league gameplay#Tackling|Tackle]] and [[Rugby league gameplay#Play-the-ball|Play-the-Ball]] * Section 12: [[Rugby league gameplay#Scrum|Scrum]] * Section 13: Penalty Kick * Section 14: Offside * Section 15: Misconduct * Section 16: [[Rugby league match officials|Referee and Touch Judges]] * Section 17: [[Rugby league match officials#Referee.27s signals|Referee's Signals]]
The current 17 sections, which include notes, are detailed in fewer than 50 pages and around 17,000 words. The Laws therefore have some flexibility to enable decisions to be made without the need to amend them. For example, Section 15, Law 1 (i) considers behaviour "in any way contrary to the true spirit of the game" to be misconduct.<ref name="ILG-2004-p38">[[#RLIF-ILG-2004|RLIF, 2004]]: 38</ref> That law has been used to prevent [[List of rugby league terms#Chicken wing|chicken-wing tackling techniques]], for example.<ref name="rfl-disciplinary">{{Cite web|url=http://www.therfl.co.uk/about/disciplinary_item.php?id=791 |publisher=The RFL |work=Disciplinary |title=Case number: ON/89/09 |author=RFL |accessdate=2009-07-30 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5n9UORpDk?url=http://www.therfl.co.uk/about/disciplinary_item.php?id=791 |archivedate=29 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="bott16-04-08">{{Cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/rugbyleague/article-1015649/RUGBY-LEAGUE-RFL-determined-stop-outlawed-chicken-wing-tackle.html |publisher=Mail Online |title=RFL determined to stop outlawed 'chicken-wing' tackle |author=Richard Bott |date=2008-04-16 |accessdate=2008-07-30 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5nM17iVVF?url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/rugbyleague/article-1015649/RUGBY-LEAGUE-RFL-determined-stop-outlawed-chicken-wing-tackle.html |archivedate= 7 February 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
==Origins==
===Rugby football=== The rules of football as played at [[Rugby School]] in the 19th century were decided regularly and informally by the pupils. For many years the rules were unwritten.<ref name="IRB-2007-10-22">{{Cite web |url=http://www.irb.com/history/halloffame/newsid=2026170.html |title=2006: The Rugby School Legacy - The Laws |author=IRB.com |date=2007-10-22 |publisher=International Rugby Board |accessdate=29 May 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5q5yhdDmY?url=http://www.irb.com/history/halloffame/newsid=2026170.html |archivedate=29 May 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> In 1845 three pupils at the school, [[William Delafield Arnold]], [[Walter Waddington Shirley]] and Frederick Leigh Hutchins were tasked with writing a codified set of rules by the then [[Head Schoolboy]] and football captain Isaac Gregory Smith.<ref name="IRB-2007-10-22"/> The three pupils submitted 37 rules which were approved on 28 August 1845.<ref name="trueman2006-laws">{{Cite web|url=http://www.rugbyfootballhistory.com/laws.htm |title=History of the Laws of Rugby Football |last=Trueman |first=Nigel |year=2006 |publisher=rugbyfootballhistory.com |accessdate=5 January 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5mYyEija4?url=http://www.rugbyfootballhistory.com/laws.htm |archivedate= 5 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="rugby-laws-1845">{{Cite web|url=http://www.rugbyfootballhistory.com/resources/Laws/Full/Rugby%20School%20Laws%201845.pdf |title=Laws of Football |author1=Delafield Arnold, William |author2=Shirley, W.W. |author3=Hutchins, Frederick |date=1845-08-28 |publisher=J.S. Crossley |accessdate=5 January 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5mYyZbezG?url=http://www.rugbyfootballhistory.com/resources/Laws/Full/Rugby%20School%20Laws%201845.pdf |archivedate= 5 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Another pupil, Charles Harcourt Chambers, illustrated the Rules.<ref name="IRB-2007-10-22"/>
The Rules played at the school continued to develop over time and as pupils left they took with them the game as they had played it.<ref name="rfumuseum-historyofgame">{{Cite web|url=http://www.rfu.com/microsites/museum/page.aspx?section=87&sectionTitle=History+of+the+Game |title=History of the game |author=RFU Museum |date= |publisher=Rugby Football Union |accessdate=29 May 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5q63sB7rF?url=http://www.rfu.com/microsites/museum/page.aspx?section%3D87%26sectionTitle%3DHistory%2Bof%2Bthe%2BGame |archivedate=29 May 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> In 1871, the [[Rugby Football Union]] (RFU) was founded with the purpose of standardising the rules for the clubs playing the Rugby style of football in England.<ref name="rfu-2009-09-16">{{Cite web|url=http://www.rfu.com/AboutTheRFU/History.aspx |title=History of the RFU |author=rfu.com |date=2009-09-16 |publisher=Rugby Football Union |accessdate=29 May 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5q61bxH6m?url=http://www.rfu.com/AboutTheRFU/History.aspx |archivedate=29 May 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The RFU invited three former pupils, all lawyers, to write the standardised rules, and they titled their work as ''laws''.<ref name="rfumuseum-historyofgame"/> In June of that year the first Laws of the Game were approved.<ref name="rfumuseum-historyofgame"/>
Unions were formed to govern the game in other countries but the English RFU continued to control the Laws until 1885.<ref name="rfumuseum-historyofgame"/> In 1884, there had been a dispute over the rules between the English and Scottish unions after a match between the two countries;<ref name="rfumuseum-historyofgame"/> this led to the formation of the [[International Rugby Board|International Rugby Football Board]] in 1886 with the intention of settling such disputes.<ref name="trueman2006-laws"/><ref name="rfumuseum-historyofgame"/> The RFU refused to join and in 1887 the members of the new organisation, [[Irish Rugby Football Union|Ireland]], [[Scottish Rugby Union|Scotland]] and [[Welsh Rugby Union|Wales]], stated that no matches would be played against England until the RFU joined and accepted its rules.<ref name="trueman2006-laws"/> In 1890 the RFU joined and in 1892 a significant revision of the laws took place.<ref name="trueman2006-laws"/>
===Rugby league=== From 1895, the year of the [[History_of_rugby_league#The_schism_in_England|schism]] in the game, the laws of rugby league were initially referred to as "Northern Union" rules, after the new governing body, and were a slight variation on the rules of rugby football as played at that time.<ref name="fagan01-04-08">{{Cite web|url=http://www.rl1908.com/History/northern-union.htm |title=To the last day of the Northern Union |last=Fagan |first=Sean |date=2008-04-01 |publisher=rl1908.com |accessdate=3 January 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5nM1asVTx?url=http://www.rl1908.com/History/northern-union.htm |archivedate= 7 February 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> What began as modifications to make the competition more entertaining to spectators continued until a distinct sport had emerged.<ref name="oralhist-rulechanges-2007">{{Cite web|url=http://www.rugbyleagueoralhistory.co.uk/subjects/view/rule-changes |title=Rule changes |year=2007 |work=Interviews |publisher=The Rugby League Oral History Project |accessdate=6 January 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5mZMMp6DE?url=http://www.rugbyleagueoralhistory.co.uk/subjects/view/rule-changes |archivedate= 6 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
Initially the rules were decided by the Northern Rugby Football Union, today's [[Rugby Football League]], the governing body for rugby league in the United Kingdom. As the sport spread to around the world, other rugby leagues were established, notably in Australia, France and New Zealand, a more international approach was adopted. In 1948, the [[Rugby League International Federation#International Rugby League Board|International Rugby League Board]] (IRLB) was formed.<ref name="edgar-ORconquer-09-98">{{Citation |last=Edgar |first=Harry | publication-date =September 1998 | date = | year =1998 |title=Can League conquer the world? |pages=14–17| periodical =Open Rugby | series = | place =Brighouse, UK | publisher =League Publications | volume = | issue =210 | issn =0958-5427}}</ref> Initially the RFL retained this responsibility for the Laws while it was seen how the new Board would develop.<ref name="goodman26-01-1948">{{Cite web|last=Goodman |first=Tom |title=Board urges trial of new R.L. rule |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article18058684 |publisher=''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]'' |accessdate=14 May 2010 |page=7 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5q5o2E9pu?url=http://newspapers.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/18058684 |archivedate=29 May 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The IRLB was invested with responsibility for the Laws later.
During the [[Super League war]], a dispute over media rights and the control of the game originating in Australia, the laws of rugby league were altered by the rival factions, the IRLB and its only remaining member, the Australian Rugby League, and the [[Super League International Board]] and its members.
Since 1998 when the different sides reunited, the Laws have been the responsibility of the [[Rugby League International Federation]].
{{Anchor|List of changes to the laws|list of changes to the laws}}<!-- Should be above the changes section title -->
==History of changes to the Laws== The Northern Rugby Football Union inherited the existing laws of rugby football, as played until that time by its member clubs. The NRFU immediately made changes. In addition to the time before 1948 when an international governing body was established, members of the International Federation and its predecessors have had the authority to make significant changes to the Laws applied within their jurisdiction.
'''The following is an incomplete list''' of changes made to the laws of rugby league since the [[History of rugby league#The schism in England|1895 schism]]. Changes to the laws used for senior competitions within the jurisdictions of RLIF members with test nation status are included here.
{{Small|Additional detail: ''Included are the flags or icons of the territory affected as well as the name of the governing body responsible and a link to the first season the change was implemented in senior competition(s) by that body. If a Law has since been changed, the Law's current status is indicated, and a link given to the year of the change in this article.''}}
===1890s=== ;1895:
[[Rugby Football League|NRFU]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1895–96 Northern Rugby Football Union season]]''.}} * During the inaugural season of rugby league, the rules were changed to require the scrum-half to retire behind a scrum until the ball was out.<ref name="fagan-pioneers-2007-p351">[[#fagan-pioneers-2007|Fagan, 2007]]: 351</ref> The scrum-half would now be deemed offside if they moved past their team's forwards while the ball was in the opposing pack.<ref name="fagan-pioneers-2007-p365">[[#fagan-pioneers-2007|Fagan, 2007]]: 365</ref> When the game was introduced to Australia several years later, the change was noted by ''[[The Sydney Sportsman]]'' on 15 April 1908 to "make the game fast and open" as it allowed the side that wins the contest for the ball to mobilise their backs "without interference".<ref name="fagan-pioneers-2007-p365"/> Before this a scrum-half had been permitted to follow the ball as it progressed through the packed forwards of their opponents half of the scrum.<ref name="fagan-pioneers-2007-p351"/>
;1896:
[[Rugby Football League|NRFU]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1896–97 Northern Rugby Football Union season]]''.}} * If a team committed a deliberate knock-on a free kick would now be awarded to the opposing team.<ref name="fagan-pioneers-2007-p351"/> Previously a scrum would have been formed in such an event.<ref name="fagan-pioneers-2007-p351"/> * The scrum-half feeding the ball into the scrum was required to do so from the same side of the scrum as the referee was positioned.<ref name="fagan-pioneers-2007-p351"/>
;1897:
[[Rugby Football League|NRFU]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1897–98 Northern Rugby Football Union season]]''.}} * The options presented to a team as a means to restart play after the ball had been kicked into touch were changed.<ref name="fagan-pioneers-2007-p351"/> The line-out was abolished and replace with the [[List of rugby league terms#Punt-out|punt-out]].<ref name="wolves1TNU">{{Cite web|url=http://www.warringtonwolves.org/HistoryB.ink |publisher=Warrington Wolves |title=The Northern Union |author=Warrington Wolves |accessdate=2009-07-06 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5k41lhoHC?url=http://www.warringtonwolves.org/HistoryB.ink |archivedate=26 September 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="RLW-iss340-aug2009-p62"/> The team would now be able to choose whether to have a scrum or a punt-out (also known as a "kick-in"), where previously the options had been to have a scrum or a line-out.<ref name="fagan-pioneers-2007-p351"/> A punt-out was taken from the touch-line by a player who could kick the ball back into play, in any direction.<ref name="fagan-pioneers-2007-p351"/> *In order to promote the scoring of tries:<ref name="fagan-pioneers-2007-p351"/> ** The value of a drop goal was reduced from four points to two points.<ref name="wolves1TNU"/><ref name="trueman25-07-09-scoring">{{Cite web|url=http://www.rugbyfootballhistory.com/scoring.htm |title=Scoring through the ages |last=Trueman |first=Nigel |date=2009-07-25 |publisher=rugbyfootballhistory.com |accessdate=6 January 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5macPK7im?url=http://www.rugbyfootballhistory.com/scoring.htm |archivedate= 6 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="RLW-iss340-aug2009-p61"/> {{Small|Amended: ''[[#1971|NSWRFL, 1971]]''.}} ** The value of a penalty goal was reduced from three points to two points.<ref name="wolves1TNU"/><ref name="trueman25-07-09-scoring"/><ref name="RLW-iss340-aug2009-p61"/> ** The value of a goal from mark was reduced from four points to two points.<ref name="wolves1TNU"/><ref name="trueman25-07-09-scoring"/><ref name="RLW-iss340-aug2009-p61"/> {{Small|Abolished: ''[[#1922|NSWRFL, 1922]]''.}} ** The value of a field goal was reduced from four points to two points.<ref name="fagan-pioneers-2007-p393">[[#fagan-pioneers-2007|Fagan, 2007]]: 393</ref> {{Small|Abolished: ''[[#1922|NSWRFL, 1922]]''.}}
;1899:
[[Rugby Football League|NRFU]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1899–1900 Northern Rugby Football Union season]]''.}} * The location of the restart after a try had been scored, either a place-kick if the try had been converted or a drop-kick if the try-scoring team was unable to convert, was moved from the 25-yard line of the non-scoring team to the halfway line.<ref name="fagan-pioneers-2007-p351"/> * After a player had been tackled a loose scrum was now ordered formed to allow the ball to be brought back into play.<ref name="fagan-pioneers-2007-p351"/><ref name="greenwood-watson-11-01">{{Cite journal|last=Greenwood |first=Bill |author2=Watson, James |date=November 2001 |title=The "Famous Northern Union Game": The Rise and Fall of Rugby League in Wanganui, 1910-15 |series=Sporting Traditions |journal=Journal of the Australian Society for Sports History |publisher=LA84 Foundation |volume=18 |issue=1 |pages=33 |url=http://www.la84foundation.org/SportsLibrary/SportingTraditions/2001/st1801/ST1801e.pdf |accessdate=2010-01-31 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5nBTr3DTD?url=http://www.la84foundation.org/SportsLibrary/SportingTraditions/2001/st1801/ST1801e.pdf |archivedate=31 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="Fagan04-04-09"/>
===1900s=== ;1900:
[[Rugby Football League|NRFU]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1900–01 Northern Rugby Football Union season]]''.}} * Defenders were banned from charging players attempting a place-kick at goal.<ref name="fagan-pioneers-2007-p351"/> * The location at which a penalty was awarded against a defender that had obstructed a kicker after the ball had been kicked was changed from where the incident took place to where the ball had landed.<ref name="fagan-pioneers-2007-p351"/>
;1901:
[[Rugby Football League|NRFU]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1901–02 Northern Rugby Football Union season]]''.}} * Should a player go into touch while in possession of the ball play would now be restarted with a scrum rather than a punt-out.<ref name="fagan-pioneers-2007-p351"/> The punt-out was retained for those times when the ball was kicked into touch.<ref name="fagan-pioneers-2007-p351"/> * The knocking-on rule was altered. While trying to catch the ball, a player would now be permitted to "juggle" it, i.e. the ball could be re-gathered if it had not been caught cleanly in the first attempt to take possession.<ref name="fagan-pioneers-2007-p351"/> Previously a "clean catch" had been required, except in instances when the ball moved backwards after touching the hands or arms, because a knock to the ball causing forward movement was classed a knock-on.<ref name="fagan-pioneers-2007-p352">[[#fagan-pioneers-2007|Fagan, 2007]]: 352</ref> * Another change to the knock-on rule meant, provided that the ball did not touch the ground, play would continue uninterrupted if a player dropped the ball into the hands of a player on the opposing team.<ref name="fagan-pioneers-2007-p352"/>
;1902:
[[Rugby Football League|NRFU]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1902–03 Northern Rugby Football Union season]]''.}} * The punt-out, or kick-in, was abolished. In the event of the ball being kicked into touch, play would restart with a scrum 10 yards infield.<ref name="fagan-pioneers-2007-p352"/>
;1903:
[[Rugby Football League|NRFU]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1903–04 Northern Rugby Football Union season]]''.}} * Kicking the ball into touch [[List of rugby league terms#on the full|on the full]], i.e. without the ball bouncing inside the field of play before going into touch, was no longer allowed for any kick except a penalty kick.<ref name="fagan-pioneers-2007-p352"/>
;1904:
[[Rugby Football League|NRFU]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1904–05 Northern Rugby Football Union season]]''.}} * A team could no longer position more than three players in the front row of a scrum.<ref name="fagan-pioneers-2007-p352"/> Previously there had been no restrictions on how many members of a team could join the front row.<ref name="fagan-pioneers-2007-p352"/> * The knocking-on rule was adjusted so that in the event the non-offending team picked up the ball after their opponents had knocked-on, and even if it had touched the ground, play would continue.<ref name="fagan-pioneers-2007-p352"/>
;1906:
[[Rugby Football League|NRFU]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1906–07 Northern Rugby Football Union season]]''.}} * The [[play-the-ball]] rule was introduced.<ref name="Fagan04-04-09">{{Cite web|url=http://www.rl1908.com/rucksinfo.htm |publisher=rl1908.com |title=The real rugby game |author=Sean Fagan |date=2009-04-04 |accessdate=2009-09-24 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5maXSkas8?url=http://www.rl1908.com/rucksinfo.htm |archivedate= 6 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Previously after each tackle had been completed or a player had been "held" the rules mandated that a [[scrum (rugby)|scrum]] be ordered by the referee.<ref name="Fagan04-04-09"/> These scrums had taken up a significant portion of game time and it was felt that the ball was hidden from spectators too often as a result, diminishing the game's entertainment value.<ref name="Fagan04-04-09"/><ref name="Fagan01-07-08">{{Cite web|url=http://rl1908.com/History/1906.htm |publisher=rl1908.com |title=A Motor Car Compared To A Bullock Wagon |author=Sean Fagan |date=2008-07-01 |accessdate=2009-09-24 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5kAryUf8h?url=http://rl1908.com/History/1906.htm |archivedate=30 September 2009 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> The play-the-ball restored the early rugby football principle that play does not carry on when the player is no longer standing, but that a tackle is complete when a player is "held" on the ground or while on their feet.<ref name="Fagan04-04-09"/> The ''[[Yorkshire Post]]'' commented on 13 June 1906 that the proposals, "provided in effect for a return to the 'play the ball' rule".<ref name="Fagan04-04-09"/> In New Zealand, a newspaper column in ''The Truth'' on 10 November 1906 while describing the sport to its readers wrote, "the most excellent rule, that was obliterated from the earlier laws of the Union has again been introduced, 'That a player, when collared, must put the ball into play'."<ref name="Fagan04-04-09"/> {{Small|Amended: ''[[#1926|NSWRFL, 1926]]''; ''[[#1927|RFL, 1927]]''.}} * The number of players on each team was reduced from fifteen to thirteen.<ref name="wolves1TNU"/><ref name="Fagan04-04-09"/> * If a ball was kicked out of play [[List of rugby league terms#on the full|on the full]], a scrum back where it had been kicked from would now be formed.<ref name="wolves1TNU"/>
;1909:
{{Flagicon|Australia}} [[New South Wales Rugby League|NSWRFL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1909 NSWRFL season]]''.}} * Teams were restricted from placing more than three players in the front row of a scrum; the other rows remained unrestricted.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present">{{Cite web|url=http://www.rl1908.com/History/rules.htm |title=The laws of rugby league: Overview of amendments: 1909-present |last=Fagan |first=Sean |date=2009-12-16 |publisher=rl1908.com |accessdate=22 December 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5mcF2ocCw?url=http://www.rl1908.com/History/rules.htm |archivedate= 8 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1908-17">[[#ARL-CofRL-2008|ARL, 2008]]: 1908-17</ref> {{Small|Amended: ''[[#1931|NSWRFL, 1931]]''.}}
===1920s=== ;1920:
{{Flagicon|Australia}} [[New South Wales Rugby League|NSWRFL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1920 NSWRFL season]]''.}} * A scrum-half was now required to feed the ball into the scrum.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1918-27">[[#ARL-CofRL-2008|ARL, 2008]]: 1918-27</ref>
;1922:
{{Flagicon|Australia}} [[New South Wales Rugby League|NSWRFL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1922 NSWRFL season]]''.}} * The goal from mark after a fair catch was abolished.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1918-27"/> * The 'field goal', which could be scored in open play by kicking a loose ball above the cross bar and between the posts, was abolished.<ref name="trueman25-07-09-scoring"/><ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1918-27"/>
;1926:
{{Flagicon|Australia}} [[New South Wales Rugby League|NSWRFL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1926 NSWRFL season]]''.}} * The goal-line drop-out replaced drop-outs from the 25-yard line after the ball was played dead by a defender.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1918-27"/> * A new version of the play-the-ball was created which consisted of two players from each team.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1918-27"/> The ball was contested by only the defending marker and tackled player who was playing the ball, the marker was required to keep both feet on the ground until the ball was dropped or placed.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1918-27"/> The other two players stood ready act as halfback should their teammate win the contest. {{small|Amended: ''[[#1997|ARL, 1997]]''.}}
;1927:
{{Flagicon|UK}} [[Rugby Football League|RFL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1927–28 Northern Rugby Football League season]]''.}} * Play-the-ball rules were amended for the [[1927–28 Northern Rugby Football League season|1927–28 season]] with the [[1926 NSWRFL season|1926]] Australian development in which the play-the-ball consisted of two defensive markers, the tackled player and the acting half-back.<ref name="Fagan04-04-09"/> {{small|Amended: ''[[#1996|RFL, 1996]]''.}}
===1930s=== ;1931:
{{Flagicon|Australia}} [[New South Wales Rugby League|NSWRFL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1931 NSWRFL season]]''.}} * The defending halfback would now feed the scrum, while the attacking side would have the loose-head.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/> Previously, the player that fed the scrum had been the attacking halfback.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/> {{Small|Amended: ''[[#1982|NSWRFL, 1982]]''.}} * It became mandatory for each team's forwards to pack-down into the scrum in a 3-2-1 formation.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/> * Scrums now had to be set a minimum of 10 yards from the touch line and a minimum of 5 yards from goal line.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/> * Players who were off-side at the time of the play-the-ball would now be penalised if they did not make an attempt to get on-side and interfere with or obstruct an opposing player.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/>
;1932:
{{Flagicon|Australia}} [[New South Wales Rugby League|NSWRFL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1932 NSWRFL season]]''.}} * A loose-arm rule is introduced, hookers must now place both arms over the props next to them.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/> * The penalty was changed to allow a team awarded one to have the option of having a scrum rather than a 'free kick'.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/>
===1940s=== ;1948:
{{Flagicon|Australia}} [[New South Wales Rugby League|NSWRFL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1948 NSWRFL season]]''.}} * The opposing front rows in a scrum were prevented from packing down against each other until ordered to do so by the referee.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1948-57">[[#ARL-CofRL-2008|ARL, 2008]]: 1948-57</ref>
===1950s=== ;1950:
{{Flagicon|UK}} [[Rugby Football League|RFL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1950–51 Northern Rugby Football League season]]''.}} * The field goal, which was scored by kicking a loose ball above the cross bar and between the posts, was abolished from the laws.<ref name="Collins-2010-09-04-fieldgoalsredux">{{cite web|last=Collins |first=Tony |authorlink=Tony Collins (historian) |title=Field goals redux: the pedants are revolting... |url=http://rugbyreloaded.blogspot.com/2010/09/field-goals-redux-pedants-are-revolting.html |date=2010-09-04 |accessdate=2011-03-29 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5xYVj02yG?url=http://rugbyreloaded.blogspot.com/2010/09/field-goals-redux-pedants-are-revolting.html |archivedate=29 March 2011 |work=[[Rugby Reloaded]] |publisher=[[Tony Collins (historian)|Tony Collins]] |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
;1951:
{{Flagicon|Australia}} [[New South Wales Rugby League|NSWRFL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1951 NSWRFL season]]''.}} * A five-yard ruck rule was introduced and applied to both teams, previously there had been a 'no-yard' ruck rule.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1948-57"/> This rule change lasted just one season.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/> {{small|Amended: ''[[#1952|NSWRFL, 1952]]''.}}
;1952:
{{Flagicon|Australia}} [[New South Wales Rugby League|NSWRFL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1952 NSWRFL season]]''.}} * The no-yard ruck rule was reinstated.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1948-57"/> {{small|Amended: ''[[#1956|NSWRFL, 1956]]''.}} * The dummy-half and second-marker were required to stand one yard behind the two men contesting the play-the-ball.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1948-57"/> {{small|Abolished: ''[[#1956|NSWRFL, 1956]]''.}}
;1954:
{{Flagicon|Australia}} [[New South Wales Rugby League|NSWRFL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1954 NSWRFL season]]''.}} * The tap penalty was introduced.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1948-57"/> {{small|Abolished: ''[[#1959|NSWRFL, 1959]]''.}} * A team conceding a penalty was required to retire 10 yards.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1948-57"/>
;1956:
{{Flagicon|Australia}} [[New South Wales Rugby League|NSWRFL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1956 NSWRFL season]]''.}} * A three-yard ruck rule replaced the no-yard ruck rule and was applicable to both teams.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1948-57"/> {{Small|Amended: ''[[#1966|NSWRFL, 1966]]''.}} * No minimum distance replaced the one-yard minimum that the dummy-half and second-marker had previously had to stand behind their teammates contesting the play-the-ball.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1948-57"/>
;1959:
{{Flagicon|Australia}} [[New South Wales Rugby League|NSWRFL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1959 NSWRFL season]]''.}} * The tap penalty was abolished.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1958-67">[[#ARL-CofRL-2008|ARL, 2008]]: 1958-67</ref> {{Small|Restored: ''[[#1967|NSWRFL, 1967]]''.}}
===1960s=== ;1961:
{{Flagicon|Australia}} [[New South Wales Rugby League|NSWRFL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1961 NSWRFL season]]''.}} * In an effort to discourage incessant and purposeless runs by the dummy-halves, a rule was made that should the dummy-half be tackled after running with the ball there would be a scrum.<ref name="ARL-CofRL-1958-67"/><ref name="stevenson25-06-07">{{Cite web|url=http://newsstore.fairfax.com.au/apps/viewDocument.ac?docID=SMH070625M26P07J2R8C |title=Attack falls for dummy |last=Stevenson |first=Andrew |date=2007-06-25 |publisher=''[[Sydney Morning Herald]]'' |pages=7 |accessdate=7 February 2010 |location=Sydney |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5nLx93tE7?url=http://newsstore.fairfax.com.au/apps/viewDocument.ac?docID=SMH070625M26P07J2R8C |archivedate= 7 February 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> {{small|Repealed: ''[[#1963|NSWRFL, 1963]]''.}}
;1963:
{{Flagicon|Australia}} [[New South Wales Rugby League|NSWRFL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1963 NSWRFL season]]''.}} * The rule that a dummy-half caught with ball would result in a scrum was rescinded. Dummy-half runs were now unrestricted.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1958-67"/> * The ball leaving the scrum was required to come out behind the second-rowers.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1958-67"/> * The non-offending team would now be given the loose-head and feed at a scrum resulting from a penalty, this included after the team had kicked into touch.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1958-67"/> {{Small|Amended: ''[[#1967|NSWRFL, 1967]]''.}} * Teams were allowed to replace a maximum of two injured players during the first half of a match and including halftime.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1958-67"/> {{Small|Amended: ''[[#1970s|NSWRFL, 1970]]''.}}
;1964:
{{Flagicon|Australia}} [[New South Wales Rugby League|NSWRFL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1964 NSWRFL season]]''.}} * Scrums would now be set a minimum of 10 yards from the goal-line.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1958-67"/> * A place kick from the halfway line was used for the kick-off restarting play after an unconverted try.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1958-67"/> * A penalty on halfway would now be awarded if a kick-off went out on the full.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1958-67"/>
;1966:
{{Flagicon|Australia}} [[New South Wales Rugby League|NSWRFL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1966 NSWRFL season]]''.}} * A five-yard ruck rule, applying to both teams, was implemented; an increase from three yards.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1958-67"/>
{{Flagicon|UK}} [[Rugby Football League|RFL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1966–67 Northern Rugby Football League season]]''.}} * A four-tackle rule was introduced in December 1966.<ref name="RLW-iss340-aug2009-p61">[[#RLW-iss340-aug2009|Top ten: Rugby league rules, ''Rugby League World'', Aug 2009]]: 61</ref> The rule ended unlimited tackles, a by-product from the introduction of the play-the-ball in 1906.<ref name="RLW-iss340-aug2009-p62">[[#RLW-iss340-aug2009|Bottom ten: Rugby league rules, ''Rugby League World'', Aug 2009]]: 62</ref><ref name="RLW-iss340-aug2009-p61"/> The sport's administrators were concerned that teams were becoming obsessed with retaining possession, as it was possible to keep the ball for long periods, to the detriment of the game being an exciting spectacle.<ref name="middleton03-08-p27">[[#middleton03-08|Middleton, 2008]]: 27</ref> A match between [[Hull Kingston Rovers]] and [[Huddersfield Giants|Huddersfield]] was a catalyst for this significant change; after Huddersfield kicked off, they were only able to touch the ball twice during the whole of the first half of the game.<ref name="middleton03-08-p27"/> Rugby Football League secretary [[Bill Fallowfield]] devised and proposed the four-tackle rule with Australian authorities supporting the change as they were experiencing similar concerns for the game in Australia and wanted to improve the game's flow and pace.<ref name="middleton03-08-p27"/><ref name="middleton03-08-p28">[[#middleton03-08|Middleton, 2008]]: 28</ref> The change had a significant impact on the style of play and helped to create a product suited to television.<ref name="middleton03-08-p28"/> {{Small|Amended: ''[[#1972|RFL, 1972]]''.}}
;1967:
{{Flagicon|Australia}} [[New South Wales Rugby League|NSWRFL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1967 NSWRFL season]]''.}} * The four-tackle rule was introduced to replace unlimited tackles.<ref name="middleton03-08-p28"/> {{Small|Amended: ''[[#1971|NSWRFL, 1971]]''.}} * The tap penalty was reintroduced following its withdrawal in 1959.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1958-67"/> * Scrums were replaced by a tap kick at restarts following penalty kicks into touch.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1958-67"/>
;1968:
{{Flagicon|Australia}} [[New South Wales Rugby League|NSWRFL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1968 NSWRFL season]]''.}} * Defending teams would restart with a 25-yard optional kick should an attacking team make the ball dead.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1968-77">[[#ARL-CofRL-2008|ARL, 2008]]: 1968-77</ref>
;1969:
{{Flagicon|Australia}} [[New South Wales Rugby League|NSWRFL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1969 NSWRFL season]]''.}} * The front-row were required to pack 'square' in scrums.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1968-77"/>
===1970s=== ;1970:
{{Flagicon|Australia}} [[New South Wales Rugby League|NSWRFL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1970 NSWRFL season]]''.}} * Two injured players were allowed to be replaced at any time during a game, provided that the replacements had played at least half of a lower-grade game that day.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1968-77"/> {{Small|Amended: ''[[#1981|NSWRFL, 1981]]''.}} *If a player goes down injured the ball is simply given to a teammate to play rather than the game being halted so a doctor can be called onto the field.<ref>{{Cite news | last = [[Sean Fagan]] | first = | title = In league, we leave the dead where they fall | work = [[The Sydney Morning Herald]] | place = Australia | pages = | language = | publisher = [[Fairfax Media]] | date = 3 October 2010 | url = http://www.smh.com.au/rugby-league/league-match-preview/in-league-we-leave-the-dead-where-they-fall-20101002-161uz.html | accessdate = 3 October 2010}}</ref>
;1971:
{{Flagicon|Australia}} [[New South Wales Rugby League|NSWRFL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1971 NSWRFL season]]''.}} * Value of a drop goal was reduced from two points to one point.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1968-77"/> * The six-tackle rule was introduced, replacing the four-tackle rule.<ref name="middleton03-08-p28"/>
;1972:
{{Flagicon|UK}} [[Rugby Football League|RFL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1972–73 Northern Rugby Football League season]]''.}} * The six-tackle rule was introduced for the 1972-73 season with the aim of alleviating the "disjointed" play experienced with the four-tackle rule.<ref name="RLW-iss340-aug2009-p61"/>
===1980s=== ;1981:
{{Flagicon|Australia}} [[New South Wales Rugby League|NSWRFL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1981 NSWRFL season]]''.}} * Temporary suspensions of players, known as the "sin-bin", are introduced for misconduct.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1978-87">[[#ARL-CofRL-2008|ARL, 2008]]: 1978-87</ref><ref name="ILG-2004-p42">[[#RLIF-ILG-2004|RLIF, 2004]]: 42</ref> * The differential scrum penalty is introduced.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1978-87"/> * Four replacements of players on the field are allowed during matches.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1978-87"/> {{Small|Amended: ''[[#1988|NSWRL, 1988]]''.}}
;1982:
{{Flagicon|Australia}} [[New South Wales Rugby League|NSWRFL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1982 NSWRFL season]]''.}} * Loose-head and feed were now given to non-offending team at the scrum.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1978-87"/>
;1983:
{{Flagicon|Australia}} [[New South Wales Rugby League|NSWRFL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1983 NSWRFL season]]''.}} * The value of try was increased from three points to four points.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1978-87"/> * The handover was introduced if a team was caught in possession after the sixth tackle.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1978-87"/> This replaced the scrum in this situation.
;1986:
{{Flagicon|Australia}} [[New South Wales Rugby League|NSWRL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1986 NSWRL season]]''.}} * A twenty-metre restart was given when the ball was caught on the full in the in-goal area by a member of the defending team.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1978-87"/>
;1987:
{{Flagicon|Australia}} [[New South Wales Rugby League|NSWRL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1987 NSWRL season]]''.}} * The 'Head-bin' was introduced for players suffering minor head injuries.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1978-87"/> The injured players were allowed to return to the field of play after 10 minutes without affecting team's quota of replacements.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1978-87"/> {{small|Replaced: ''[[#1991|NSWRL, 1991]]''.}} * A team that kicked the ball into touch in own half of the field, up to the fourth tackle, was awarded the ball feed at the following scrum.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/> This rule was suspended before the 1987 NSWRL season play-offs.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/> {{small|Repealed: ''[[#1987|NSWRL, 1987]]''.}}
;1988:
{{Flagicon|Australia}}<!-- In this season the Queensland based Brisbane Broncos entered the competition --> [[New South Wales Rugby League|NSWRL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1988 NSWRL season]]''.}} * Two fresh replacements were now allowed, previously they had had to have played in a lower-grade game earlier.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1988-97">[[#ARL-CofRL-2008|ARL, 2008]]: 1988-97</ref> {{small|Amended: ''[[#1991|NSWRL, 1991]]''.}}
;1989:
{{Flagicon|Australia}} [[New South Wales Rugby League|NSWRL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1989 NSWRL season]]''.}} * The use of the handover was extended to those occasions on the sixth tackle when the attacking team knocked on, kicked out on the full, or ran into touch.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/> * When a scrum took place, all players standing outside it, apart from the halfback, had to stand a minimum of 5 metres back to be onside.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/>
===1990s=== ;1990:
{{Flagicon|Australia}} [[New South Wales Rugby League|NSWRL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1990 NSWRL season]]''.}} * In-goal touch judges were introduced for the finals series.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1988-97"/> * Any players chasing their team's kick from an offside position were required to remain 10 metres away from the opponent taking possession of the ball.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/> This was an increase from 5 metres.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/>
;1991:
{{Flagicon|Australia}} [[New South Wales Rugby League|NSWRL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1991 NSWRL season]]''.}} * A penalty would now be given against a defender guilty of stripping the ball from opponent in possession.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/> * The interchange rule was introduced, it allowed four players, consisting of up to two fresh reserves and a minimum of two players who had played half a game of the preceding Reserve Grade or President's Cup, unlimited interchanges during a match.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1988-97"/> The rule's main purpose was to reduce the risk of blood-borne diseases being spread but an angry public reaction forced a modification in April.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1988-97"/> The rule changed to allow a total of four players to be available for a maximum of six interchanges during a match.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1988-97"/> Players sent to the ‘blood-bin' would not count among these six interchanges.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1988-97"/> {{small|Amended: ''[[#1996|ARL, 1996]]''.}}
;1993:
[[Rugby League International Federation#International Rugby League Board|IRLB]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1993 NSWRL season]]''.}} * A new definition was agreed for a high tackle which stated that it was illegal to make contact with the head or neck whether it was done "intentionally, recklessly or carelessly".<ref name="smh13-03-1993">{{Cite web|url=http://newsstore.fairfax.com.au/apps/viewDocument.ac?docID=news930313_0121_6557 |title=Rugby league's 8 hot potatoes of '93 |last=Williams |first=Daniel |author2=Sarno, Tony |author3=Masters, Roy |author4=Magnay, Jacquelin |author5=Mcadonald, John |date=1993-03-13 |publisher=''[[Sydney Morning Herald]]'' |pages=73 |accessdate=16 March 2010 |location=Sydney |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5oH1GWrpX?url=http://newsstore.fairfax.com.au/apps/viewDocument.ac?docID=news930313_0121_6557 |archivedate=16 March 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Some coaches, such as [[Tim Sheens]], voiced concerns that the rule was flawed because it would penalise accidental contact with the head or neck but Mick Stone, the NSWRL referees coaching co-ordinator, dismissed this stating accidental contact was not necessarily covered by the definition of "intentionally, recklessly, or carelessly".<ref name="smh13-03-1993"/> * The ball could be fed into the scrum providing that it entered between the opposing [[Rugby league positions#The front row|front-rowers]]' outside feet.<ref name="smh13-03-1993"/> This change meant referees would no longer need to check that the [[Rugby league positions#Scrum half|scrum half]] had put the ball into the middle of the scrum tunnel.<ref name="smh13-03-1993"/> Mick Stone said the new ruling gave referees "a very tangible line to look at".<ref name="smh13-03-1993"/> Stone said, "if the ball [enters] behind the front-rowers' foot, bang, it's a penalty".<ref name="smh13-03-1993"/> Stone believed that the ruling was an improvement on the situation during the previous season in Australia when the ball was being fed "under the [[Rugby league positions#Second-row forward|second-rowers]]' or locks' ([[Rugby league positions#Loose forward / Lock forward|loose-forward]]) feet", he believed the change would "allow the halfback (scrum-half) a fair amount of latitude" while giving "the side without the feed a look at the ball".<ref name="smh13-03-1993"/>
{{Flagicon|Australia}} [[New South Wales Rugby League|NSWRL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1993 NSWRL season]]''.}} * The distance the defensive line were taken back by the referee at the play-the-ball would now be measured from where the tackled player places the ball to play it.<ref name="smh13-03-1993"/> Previously the distance had been measured from the back foot of the [[List of rugby league terms#marker|marker]] but Mick Stone, the referees coaching coordinator, felt that this led to "fives" of varying lengths depending on where the markers stood.<ref name="smh13-03-1993"/> * The defensive line at the play-the-ball would now be taken back 8 metres instead of 5 metres to compensate for the change in the position the distance was measured from.<ref name="smh13-03-1993"/> The 8 metre distance was amended mid-season. {{small|Amended: ''[[#1993|NSWRL, 1993]]''.}} * A ten-metre offside rule was introduced mid-season for non-markers on the defending team at the play-the-ball, amending the 8 metre rule introduced at the beginning of the season.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1988-97"/>
;1994:
{{Flagicon|UK}} [[Rugby Football League|RFL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1994–95 Rugby Football League season]]''.}} * Referees were given the power to put a player suspected of foul play "on report" with the incident to be reviewed later by the disciplinary panel.<ref name="hadfield22-03-95">{{Cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/rugby-league-trio-face-referee-reports-1612327.html |publisher=The Independent |title=Trio face referee reports |author=Dave Hadfield |date=1995-03-22 |accessdate=2009-05-06 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5ghhVYfoJ?url=http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/rugby-league-trio-face-referee-reports-1612327.html |archivedate=12 May 2009 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> The system was based on the one already operating in Australian rugby league.<ref name="hadfield22-03-95"/> Referees signalled that an incident had been put "on report" by crossing their raised arms above their heads.<ref name="bbc27-10-04">{{Cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sportacademy/hi/sa/rugby_league/rules/referee_signals/newsid_3730000/3730046.stm |publisher=BBC |title=Referee signals: Incident on report/holding down a tackled player |author=BBC Sport |date=2004-10-27 |accessdate=2009-05-06 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5nM23Po2X?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sportacademy/hi/sa/rugby_league/rules/referee_signals/newsid_3730000/3730046.stm |archivedate= 7 February 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> * [[Rugby league match officials#In-goal judge|In-goal judge]]s were trialled, these two additional match officials are positioned behind the dead-ball line at each end of the [[Rugby league playing field|playing field]] and aim to aid the referee in judging if a try has been scored.<ref name="hadfield22-03-95"/> The in-goal judges had been used in Australia for two years.<ref name="hadfield22-03-95"/> * Referees penalised defending players lifting attackers in the tackle in a way that could lead to an illegal [[spear tackle]].<ref name="hadfield22-03-95"/>
;1996:
[[Super League International Board|SLIB]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[Super League (Australia)#World Nines|1996 Super League World Nines]]''.}} * The video referee was used for the first time.<ref name="sutton13-03-09">{{Cite web |url=http://www.foxsports.com.au/story/0,8659,25183208-5017974,00.html |title=Going to the tape |last=Sutton |first=Christopher |date=2009-03-13 |work=The Innovators: Great ideas in sport |publisher=''[[Fox Sports (Australia)|Fox Sports]]'' |accessdate=7 January 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5mbeOqA45?url=http://www.foxsports.com.au/story/0,8659,25183208-5017974,00.html |archivedate=7 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The video referee could be used when the match referee was not sure a try had been scored and wanted to check if a player had stayed in the field of play, if the player had grounded the ball correctly, double movements, if there had been any obstruction, and whether the players involved in the "immediate passage leading up the potential try being scored" were onside or offside.<ref name="sutton13-03-09"/>
{{Flagicon|Australia}}{{Flagicon|New Zealand}}<!-- The NZ based Auckland Warriors had joined in 1995 --> [[Australian Rugby League|ARL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1996 ARL season]]''.}} * Unlimited interchanges were re-introduced.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1988-97"/> {{small|Amended: ''[[#2001|NRL, 2001]]''.}} {{Flagicon|UK}} {{Flagicon|France}}<!-- French side PSG participated --> [[Rugby Football League|RFL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[Super League I]]''.}} * Scrums were now to be set 20 metres from the [[Rugby league playing field|touch-line]], with the aim of creating attacking opportunities.<ref name="hadfield13-12-95">{{Cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/rugby-league-changes-usher-in-new-ball-game-1525565.html |publisher=The Independent |title=Changes usher in new ball game |author=Dave Hadfield |date=1995-12-13 |accessdate=2009-05-06 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5nM2O7ro8?url=http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/rugby-league-changes-usher-in-new-ball-game-1525565.html |archivedate= 7 February 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> * At the restart after a try had been scored and the conversion attempt had been taken, the side that scored now kicked off to the other team.<ref name="hadfield13-12-95"/> This change aimed to make contests more even by almost guaranteeing possession for the side that had conceded points.<ref name="hadfield13-12-95"/> [[Greg McCallum]], the director of referees' coaching, also noted that this convention was "in line with most other sports" and "that is significant when we come to promoting the game in America and Asia".<ref name="hadfield13-12-95"/> * At the [[Rugby league gameplay#Play-the-ball|play-the-ball]], the side not in possession was barred from striking for the ball.<ref name="hadfield13-12-95"/> This was an attempt to clean up the ruck.<ref name="hadfield13-12-95"/> * At the play-the-ball, the tackled player was stopped from being able to tap the ball forwards to himself - even in the absence of markers.<ref name="hadfield13-12-95"/>
;1997:
{{Flagicon|Australia}}<!-- The NZ based Auckland Warriors had aligned with Super League (Australia) --> [[Australian Rugby League|ARL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1997 ARL season]]''.}} * Striking by the defending marker at the play-the-ball was banned.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1988-97"/> * The requirement for the attacking team to stand a minimum distance behind dummy-half at the play-the-ball was ended.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1988-97"/> * The [[Rugby league gameplay#40-20 kick|40/20 rule]] was introduced to reward accurate kicking in general play and to disrupt the pattern of teams having turns at sets of six tackles.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1988-97"/><ref name="masters18-04-97">{{Cite web|url=http://newsstore.fairfax.com.au/apps/viewDocument.ac?docID=news970418_0031_0081 |title=Who's winning |last=Masters |first=Roy |date=1997-04-18 |publisher=Sydney Morning Herald |accessdate=7 January 2010 |location=Sydney |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5mcBks5FJ?url=http://newsstore.fairfax.com.au/apps/viewDocument.ac?docID=news970418_0031_0081 |archivedate= 7 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The rule gave the loose head and feed at the resulting [[Scrum (rugby)#Rugby league|scrum]] to a team that kicked the ball from behind their 40-metre line so that it bounced in the [[Rugby league playing field|field of play]] before going into touch behind their opponent's 20 metre line.<ref name="RLW-iss340-aug2009-p61"/><ref name="BBC-40/20kick-12-09-2005">{{Cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/rugby_league/rules_and_equipment/4216338.stm |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |title=The 40/20 kick |author=BBC Sport |date=2005-09-12 |accessdate=2009-09-23 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5nM2YCnag?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/rugby_league/rules_and_equipment/4216338.stm |archivedate= 7 February 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The rule also encouraged the defenders, usually wingers and fullbacks, to make a play for the ball instead of allowing it to leave play.<ref name="masters18-04-97"/> * New guidelines were introduced to combat 'dangerous throws'.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1988-97"/> * Tackled players were banned from playing the ball forward to themselves.<ref name="masters18-04-97"/> There was some concern that this could stifle play if a supporting teammate was slow to move into the [[Rugby league positions#dummy half|dummy-half]] position to allow a play-the-ball.<ref name="masters18-04-97"/>
{{Flagicon|Australia}}{{Flagicon|NZ}} [[Super League (Australia)|SL (A)]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1997 Super League (Australia) season]]''.}} * The [[Rugby league match officials#Video referee|video referee]] used.<ref name="fagan15-01-05">{{Cite web|url=http://www.rl1908.com/Grandfinals/super-league.htm |title=1997 - The Super League competition |last=Fagan |first=Sean |date=2005-01-15 |publisher=rl1908.com |accessdate=7 January 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5mbg0d70w?url=http://www.rl1908.com/Grandfinals/super-league.htm |archivedate= 7 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> {{Small|Adopted: ''[[#1998|NRL, 1998]]''.}} * The [[zero tackle]] rule was introduced.<ref name="fagan15-01-05"/> Defending teams were given an extra tackle when they received the ball if their player ran it back rather than allowing the ball to leave play if, for example, the attacking team kicked the ball.<ref name="masters18-04-97"/> This was an attempt to reward positive play and break the cycle of teams taking turns to have six tackles.<ref name="masters18-04-97"/> {{Small|Adopted: ''[[#1998|NRL, 1998]]''.}} * Tackled players were banned from playing the ball forward to themselves.<ref name="masters18-04-97"/> As with the equivalent change by the ARL, there was some concern that this could stifle play.<ref name="masters18-04-97"/> * The kick-off following points being scored was altered so that the non-scoring team was to receive the kick.<ref name="masters18-04-97"/> One intention of this change was to "narrow the gap between good and bad teams".<ref name="masters18-04-97"/>
;1998:
{{Flagicon|Australia}}{{Flagicon|New Zealand}} [[National Rugby League|NRL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[1998 NRL season]]''.}} * The Zero tackle was adopted for the unified competition.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1998-07">[[#ARL-CofRL-2008|ARL, 2008]]: 1998-07</ref><!-- Was it also amended? --> * The video referee was adopted.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1998-07"/>
;1999:
{{Flagicon|UK}} [[Rugby Football League|RFL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[Super League IV]]''.}} * The 40/20 rule was introduced.<ref name="wilson09-08-04">{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2004/aug/09/rugbyleague.andywilson |publisher=The Guardian |title=Moran leaves Vikings with a sinking feeling |author=Andy Wilson |date=2004-08-09 |accessdate=2009-05-06 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5nM2l5lfV?url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/sport/2004/aug/09/rugbyleague.andywilson |archivedate= 7 February 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="hadfield24-05-99">{{Cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/rugby-league-saints-restore-faith-in-game-with-emphasis-on-attack-1095577.html |publisher=The Independent |title=Saints restore faith in game with emphasis on attack |author=Dave Hadfield |date=1999-05-24 |accessdate=2009-05-06 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5nM2uDFra?url=http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/rugby-league-saints-restore-faith-in-game-with-emphasis-on-attack-1095577.html |archivedate= 7 February 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The 40/20 had been used in Australia since 1997.<ref name="RLW-iss340-aug2009-p61"/>
===2000s=== ;2001:
{{Flagicon|Australia}}{{Flagicon|New Zealand}} [[National Rugby League|NRL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[2001 NRL season]]''.}} * A defending player jumping to catch the ball from an opponent's kick cannot be tackled mid-air.<ref name="Stone03-04-03">{{Cite web|url=http://www.arlra.org.au/pdf-files/coachmemo03.03.pdf |title=Memorandum: MS003/03 |last=Stone |first=Michael |date=2003-04-03 |publisher=Australian Rugby League Referees' Association |accessdate=12 January 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5mifvUwYy?url=http://www.arlra.org.au/pdf-files/coachmemo03.03.pdf |archivedate=12 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> This rule was brought in due to safety consideration.<ref name="Stone03-04-03"/> The rule allows for defending players to tackle the attacking players in the air.<ref name="Stone03-04-03"/> There had been concerns from coaches that allowing an attacker to land with the ball before attempting a tackle could result in "uncontested tries" or a penalty try if a tackle was attempted while they were in the air; either of these scenarios was considered against the principles of the game.<ref name="Stone03-04-03"/><!-- according to the source this may be an amendment of an earlier rule --> * A team that finds touch with a kick from a 20-metre optional restart is awarded the loose head and feed at the scrum.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/> * If from a kick anywhere on the field, the defending team takes the ball dead, for example if they place one foot over the dead ball line before playing at the ball, the team must restart play with a goal-line drop-out.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/> * The defending team were allowed to strip the ball in the tackle if no more than two tacklers were in attendance.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/> * Limited interchanges were reintroduced, a maximum of 12 interchanges were now allowed using a pool of 4 replacements.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1998-07"/> {{Small|Amended: ''[[#2008|NRL, 2008]]''.}}
{{Flagicon|UK}} [[Rugby Football League|RFL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[Super League VI]]''.}} * 20 metre restarts should be allowed to happen quickly and not be delayed by referees.<ref name="bbc02-03-01rules">{{Cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/rugby_league/1197648.stm |publisher=BBC |title=Super League rules revamp |author=BBC Sport |date=2001-03-02 |accessdate=2009-05-06 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5nM0NcbG0?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/rugby_league/1197648.stm |archivedate= 7 February 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> * The first and second halves would end the moment that the hooter sounds, in the past referees could use their discretion to let play continue if they felt the siren had sounded in during play.<ref name="bbc02-03-01rules"/>
;2003:
{{Flagicon|UK}} [[Rugby Football League|RFL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[Super League VIII]]''.}} * The [[List of rugby league terms#K|knock-on]] rule was modified so that if in the referee's judgement a player did not play at the ball, a knock-on would not be given.<ref name="bbc20-02-03rules">{{Cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/rugby_league/super_league/2781243.stm |publisher=BBC |title=Sculthorpe questions rule changes |author=BBC Sport |date=2003-02-20 |accessdate=2009-05-06 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5nM0Xg9EE?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/rugby_league/super_league/2781243.stm |archivedate= 7 February 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> * New interchange and substitution rules were introduced.<ref name="french16-05-02rules">{{Cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/bbc_pundits/1991167.stm |publisher=BBC |title=All change, please |author=Ray French |date=2002-05-16 |accessdate=2009-05-06 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5nM0kNubC?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/bbc_pundits/1991167.stm |archivedate= 7 February 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The number of interchanges, which now included [[Blood replacement|blood bins]], increased from 6 to 12 using a pool of 4 substitutes.<ref name="bbc20-02-03rules"/><ref name="french16-05-02rules"/> This change aimed to retain the element of wearing down a team's opponents during the game - which was considered part of the character of the sport.<ref name="french16-05-02rules"/> [[Stuart Cummings]], the [[Rugby Football League]]'s technical controller said the changes "bring us into line with the international rules" and ruled out future increases as well as declaring, "We will never see the unlimited interchange introduced into rugby league in Britain," a change that had caused controversy in Australia during its experiment there.<ref name="french16-05-02rules"/>
;2004:
{{Flagicon|Australia}}{{Flagicon|New Zealand}} [[National Rugby League|NRL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[2004 NRL season]]''.}} * Should an attacking player be held up by defenders in-goal, they should carry on play with a play-the-ball on the 10 metre line.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/><ref name="ARL-CofRL-1998-07"/>
;2006:
{{Flagicon|Australia}}{{Flagicon|New Zealand}} [[National Rugby League|NRL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[2006 NRL season]]''.}} * Taps from penalty kicks to touch were now to be taken 20 metres infield.<ref name="ARL-CofRL-1998-07"/><!-- <ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/> says the taps being taken 20 metres in happened in 2007. --> {{small|Amended: ''[[#2009|NRL, 2009]]''.}}
;2008:
{{Flagicon|Australia}}{{Flagicon|New Zealand}} [[National Rugby League|NRL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[2008 NRL season]]''.}} * The maximum number of interchanges that could be made from a pool of four replacements was reduced from 12 to 10.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/> * A second tackler was now permitted to strip the ball if the attacker carrying it was attempting to place ball for a try.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/>
{{Flagicon|UK}}{{Flagicon|France}}<!-- Catalans Dragons participating --> [[Rugby Football League|RFL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[Super League XIII]]''.}} * If a team kicks the ball from a 20-metre restart and the ball bounces into touch or over the dead ball line they will be given head and feed at the resulting scrum.<ref name="Jackson30-12-07">{{Cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,12216_3012163,00.html |publisher=Sky Sports |title=Super League rule changes |author=Phil Jackson |date=2007-12-30 |accessdate=2009-07-24 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5nM02ZZKb?url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0%2C19528%2C12216_3012163%2C00.html |archivedate= 7 February 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> * In the scrum the ball can no longer be trapped by the loose forward in an attempt to catch the opposition offside.<ref name="Jackson30-12-07"/> If the scrum moves forwards and the ball comes from between and behind the inner feet of the second row forwards it will be deemed to be out of the scrum.<ref name="Jackson30-12-07"/> * Defenders, excluding the markers at a play-the-ball, must stand with both feet behind the referee's front foot to be judged onside.<ref name="Jackson30-12-07"/> * If over their try-line the defenders steal the ball from the attacking team when there is more than one defender involved in the tackle a penalty will be given rather than a penalty try.<ref name="Jackson30-12-07"/>
;2009:
{{Flagicon|Australia}}{{Flagicon|New Zealand}} [[National Rugby League|NRL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[2009 NRL season]]''.}} * An assistant on-field referee was introduced.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/> * A penalty can be applied by the referee against a defender where the attacking kicker has been tackled whilst they are in the air.<ref name="Fagan-laws-1909-present"/> * The tap from penalty kick to touch to be taken 10 metres infield.<ref name="ARL-CofRL-1998-07"/>
===2010s=== ;2010:
{{Flagicon|UK}}{{Flagicon|France}} [[Rugby Football League|RFL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[Super League XIV]]''.}} * [[Rugby league match officials#Referee|Referees]] would now call "[[List of rugby league terms#held|held]]" if one of the ball-carrier's legs was lifted by a defender in a tackle in which the participants were stood upright.<ref name="rlcom-rules-15-01-10">{{Cite web|url=http://www.rugbyleague.com/rugby-league-news/new-rule-interpretations-for-2010.html |title=New rule interpretations for 2010 |date=2010-01-15 |publisher=rugbyleague.com |accessdate=15 January 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5mnvipTof?url=http://www.rugbyleague.com/rugby-league-news/new-rule-interpretations-for-2010.html |archivedate=15 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Previously, a referee would only declare the tackle complete if both legs had been lifted.<ref name="rlcom-rules-15-01-10"/> The change was intended to increase player safety.<ref name="rlcom-rules-15-01-10"/> * Referees now called held as soon as they see the ball-carrier being dragged by more than one defender.<ref name="rlcom-rules-15-01-10"/> This rule interpretation was intended to increase player safety by preventing groups of defenders dragging an opponent into [[List of rugby league terms#touch|touch]] or the [[List of rugby league terms#in-goal|in-goal area]].<ref name="rlcom-rules-15-01-10"/>
{{Flagicon|Australia}}{{Flagicon|New Zealand}} [[National Rugby League|NRL]] {{Small|Implemented: ''[[2010 NRL season]]''.}} * During the 2010 season, a rule change to the [[rugby league playing field|playing field]] was implemented so that if a player in possession of the ball made contact with the corner post that player would no longer be considered to be [[List of rugby league terms#touch in-goal|touch in-goal]].<ref name="heraldsun-corner-post-02-06-10">{{Cite web|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/sport/nrl/finally-nrl-dumps-corner-posts/story-e6frfgbo-1225874669975 |title=Finally, NRL dumps corner posts |date=2010-06-02 |publisher=heraldsun.com.au |accessdate=25 June 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5qlMFRIpj?url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/sport/nrl/finally-nrl-dumps-corner-posts/story-e6frfgbo-1225874669975 |archivedate=26 June 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Proponents of the move argued a series a possible future scenarios made this preventative measure necessary, with [[Australian Rugby League|ARL]] chief executive [[Geoff Carr]] stating, "no one has thought of the possibility of using the corner post as a weapon to defuse a try and we want to stop it before they do".<ref name="masters2010-04-14">{{Cite web|last=Masters |first=Roy |title=Carr wants corner posts out of the field of play |url=http://www.smh.com.au/rugby-league/league-news/carr-wants-corner-posts-out-of-the-field-of-play-20100413-s7ob.html |publisher=''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]'' |accessdate=2010-08-17 |authorlink=Roy Masters (sport) |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5s3LEFdf0?url=http://www.smh.com.au/rugby-league/league-news/carr-wants-corner-posts-out-of-the-field-of-play-20100413-s7ob.html |archivedate=17 August 2010 |date=2010-04-14 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> One scenario was that a defending player might manipulate the corner post to put an attacker out of play.<ref name="masters2010-04-14"/> Another concern cited was that the corner post might be made to make contact with a rolling ball to ensure the defending team gains possession with a [[List of rugby league terms#20 metre restart|20 metre restart]].<ref name="masters2010-04-14"/> Corner posts, which sometimes lean to one side, have no upper height limit set and this led to a fear that corner posts might become "long rubber snakes, biting attackers and sending them into touch", in the words of [[Roy Masters (sport)|Roy Masters]].<ref name="masters2010-04-14"/> Other laws concerning the corner posts remained unchanged.<ref name="nrl-corner-post2010-06-02">{{Cite web|title=NRL changes rules to corner post & player registration |url=http://www.nrl.com/NewsViews/LatestNews/NewsArticle/tabid/10874/newsId/58898/Default.aspx |publisher=''[[National Rugby League]]'' |accessdate=2010-08-17 |author=NRL |authorlink=National Rugby League |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5s3X4YyUq?url=http://www.nrl.com/NewsViews/LatestNews/NewsArticle/tabid/10874/newsId/58898/Default.aspx |archivedate=17 August 2010 |date=2010-06-02 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> A ball that makes contact with the corner post while not in the possession of a player will be deemed to be touch in-goal as before.<ref name="nrl-corner-post2010-06-02"/> There was no attempt to remove the corner posts from the playing field as they are used to promote sponsors and are also a useful aid for players to judge their kicks.<ref name="masters2010-04-14"/> The change was agreed by the NRL Board and approved by the RLIF as an experimental rule.<ref name="heraldsun-corner-post-02-06-10"/> Implementation occurred mid-season following feedback from clubs.<ref name="heraldsun-corner-post-02-06-10"/>

{{EngvarB|date=May 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2014}} {{multiple issues| {{recentism|date=March 2014}} {{update|date=March 2014}} }} {{Infobox company | name = Life Style Sports | logo = Life Style Sports Logo(small).jpg | slogan = | foundation = 1979 | location = [[Mary St]], [[Dublin (city)|Dublin]] | type = [[Subsidiary]] | industry = Retail | products = Clothing
[[Sportswear (activewear)|Sportswear]] [[Fashion accessory|Accessories]] | locations = 53 stores | key_people = Mark Stafford (CEO) | owner = Stafford family | parent = Stafford Group | homepage = [http://www.lifestylesports.com lifestylesports.com] | footnotes = }} '''Life Style Sports (Ireland) Limited''' is Ireland's largest sports retailer, operating 53 outlets spread across the [[Republic of Ireland]] and [[Northern Ireland]]. They stock [[sporting goods]] and sport fashions. == History == [[File:Life Style Sports Flagship Store, Mary Street, Dublin 1, 2014.jpg|thumb|300px|Life Style Sports in Mary Street, [[Dublin]]]] Life Style Sports was established in 1979 in the Republic of Ireland by [[Quinnsworth]], a subsidiary of Associated British Foods.[http://www.lifestylesports.com/en/restofworld/page/storysofar] In 1997 it was bought by [[Tesco]] PLC but was later spun off via a [[management buy-out]] of seven directors, led by MD Andrew Sharkey and [[venture capital]] firm, ACT. In November 2005, it was acquired by Stafford Holdings – an Irish family-owned company who stated, "This latest acquisition is in line with its stated strategy of seeking acquisition opportunities in new sectors which offer strong growth potential, while maintaining a strong commitment to its current portfolio of businesses."[http://www.rte.ie/news/2005/1129/stafford-business.html Stafford Holdings buys Lifestyle Sports – RTÉ News]. Rte.ie (30 January 2009). In 2006, former [[Dunnes Stores]] senior director Eoin McGettigan was appointed CEO.[http://www.rte.ie/news/2006/1108/sports-business.html Lifestyle Sports names Dunnes Executive as CEO – RTÉ News]. Rte.ie (26 January 2007). Mark Stafford took up the role of chairman. In early 2009, Mark Stafford replaced McGettigan as CEO. He was joined by former [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] Ireland general manager Nigel Cowman as Finance Director, Dan Ryan from Penneys and Brown Thomas as Trading Director. In September 2007 a new flagship store opened in the [[Blanchardstown Centre]], [[Dublin]]. This remained their largest store, at {{convert|21000|sqft}}.[http://www.irishjobs.ie/member.asp?Mid=1267 Lifestyle Sports Ltd Jobs – Jobs in Ireland]. irishjobs.ie. until 2017. In July 2017, the company's new flagship store opened in The Capitol building [[St Patrick's Street]] in [[Cork (city)|Cork]].https://www.businessworld.ie/news/Life-Style-Sports-opens-new-flagship-store-in-Cork-568838.html In 2013, Life Style Sports became the official retail partner of [[Leinster Rugby]], with a Life Style Sports store located in [[Donnybrook Stadium]] and the [[Royal Dublin Society|Royal Dublin Society (RDS)]], home of Leinster Rugby.[http://www.leinsterrugby.ie/news/10535.php#.U58VmJRdXTo] Life Style Sports is also the official retail partner of [[Munster Rugby]].[http://www.lifestylesports.com/en/restofworld/rugby/munster-rugby/icat/page/rugbymunsterrugbyabout] === Timeline of notable company events === * 1979 – Life Style Sports opens for business in the Republic of Ireland by Power Supermarkets Limited. * 1997 – Life Style Sports expands to 32 stores nationwide. * 2000 – [[Sienna Miller]] appears in the Life Style Sports [[Cinderella]] TV advert. * 2004 – [[The Killers|The Killers']] single [[Mr. Brightside]] debuts on the Life Style Sports TV advert. * 2005 – Company acquired by Stafford Holdings, an Irish family-owned company. * 2009 – [[MTV]] presenter, Natasha Gilbert, stars in the first ever Life Style Sports Woman's Fitness Campaign "Your Life, Your Style, Your World”. * 2011 – New Life Style Sports brand identity launched. * 2012 – New flagship stores on Mary Street and in [[Dundrum Town Centre]], both in Dublin, are opened. * 2012 – Life Style Sports relaunched its website as a full e-commerce site. * 2017 - A new flagship store was launched in Cork.https://www.businessworld.ie/news/Life-Style-Sports-opens-new-flagship-store-in-Cork-568838.html == See also == * [[Tesco Ireland]] == References == {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.lifestylesports.com Lifestyle Sports website] [[Category:Sporting goods retailers]] [[Category:Clothing retailers of Ireland]] [[Category:1979 establishments in Ireland]] [[Category:Retail companies established in 1979]]

{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Luzhniki Palace of Sports | nickname = | native_name = | former_names = Palace of Sports of the Central Lenin Stadium (1956–1992) | image = Luzhniki-sports-palace.jpg | caption = | location = [[Khamovniki District]], [[Moscow]], [[Russia]] | publictransit = {{MOSMETRO-bull|1|}} [[Sportivnaya (Moscow Metro)|Sportivnaya]]
{{MOSMETRO-bull|14|}} [[Luzhniki (Moscow Central Circle)|Luzhniki]] | coordinates = | opened = 1956 | renovated = 2002 | owner = | surface = | construction_cost = | architect = | tenants = | seating_capacity = 11,500 (formerly 13,700) | website = {{URL|www.luzhniki.ru}} }} '''Luzhniki Palace of Sports''', formerly the '''Palace of Sports of the Central Lenin Stadium''', is a sports arena in Moscow, Russia, a part of the [[Luzhniki Olympic Complex]]. Built in 1956, it originally had a spectator capacity of 13,700. In the past it was the host site of the world and European championships in [[ice hockey]], [[gymnastics]], [[volleyball]], [[basketball]], [[boxing]], [[skateboarding]] and other sports. It hosted several games during the 1972 [[Summit Series]] ice hockey tournament between the [[Soviet Union national ice hockey team|Soviet Union]] and [[Canada men's national ice hockey team|Canada]] and was a venue for [[Gymnastics at the 1980 Summer Olympics|gymnastics]] and [[Judo at the 1980 Summer Olympics|judo]] events at the [[1980 Summer Olympics]].[http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1980/or1980v2pt1.pdf 1980 Summer Olympics official report.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081118143909/http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1980/or1980v2pt1.pdf |date=2008-11-18 }} Volume 2. Part 1. pp. 58–60. In 2002, the arena experienced a major reconstruction and the [[seating capacity]] was lowered to 11,500. The arena subsequently hosted the [[2005 World Figure Skating Championships]]. It was primarily used for [[ice hockey]] as the home arena for [[HC Dynamo Moscow]] until the year 2000,[http://www.dynamo.ru/stadium.php Стадион] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090519075323/http://www.dynamo.ru/stadium.php |date=2009-05-19 }} {{ru icon}} in which the club moved to [[Luzhniki Small Sports Arena]]. ==Notable sporting events== * 1956, 1959, 1963, 1967, 1971, and 1979 [[Spartakiad|Spartakiad of the Peoples of the USSR]][http://www.luzhniki.ru/ds_history.aspx?id=142 History of the palace of the sport] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081022150018/http://www.luzhniki.ru/ds_history.aspx?id=142 |date=2008-10-22 }}{{icon ru}} * [[EuroBasket 1965]] * [[1957 Ice Hockey World Championships|1957]], [[1973 World Ice Hockey Championships|1973]], [[1979 World Ice Hockey Championships|1979]], and [[1986 World Ice Hockey Championships|1986]] [[Ice Hockey World Championships]] * [[1959 FIBA World Championship for Women|1959]] [[FIBA World Championship for Women]] * 1986 [[Goodwill Games]] * [[1962 FIVB Volleyball Men's World Championship|1962 men's]] and [[1962 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship|women's]] Volleyball World Championships * Games 5–8 of the 1972 Canada-USSR ice hockey [[Summit Series]] * Games 5–8 of the [[1974 Summit Series|1974 series against Canada]] * [[2001 UEFA Futsal Championship]] ==Notable concerts== * [[Big Country]] – 1988 * [[Cannibal Corpse]] – 1993 * [[Scorpions (band)|Scorpions]] – 1997 * [[Scooter (band)|Scooter]] – 2000 * [[Rammstein]] – 2001 * [[Judas Priest]] - 2005 * [[Kraftwerk]] – 2004 * [[Depeche Mode]] & [[The Bravery]] – 2006 * [[Muse (band)|Muse]] – 2007 * [[Dream Theater]], [[Nightwish]] – 2009 * [[Smokie (band)|Smokie]] – 2011 ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081022150024/http://www.luzhniki.ru/eng/brief.aspx?id=23 Official website] {{coord|55.722440|N|37.547525|E|region:RU_type:landmark|display=title}} {{S-start-collapsible|header={{S-sta|et}}}} {{succession box | title=[[Ice Hockey World Championships]]
