{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2012}} {{More citations needed|date=December 2009}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Memorial Stadium | image = UCONNMemorialStadium.jpg | image_size = 300px | location = Stadium Road
Storrs, CT 06269 | coordinates = {{Coord|41|48|16|N|72|15|19|W|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | opened = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Connecticut|State of Connecticut]] | operator = | surface = | construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = | tenants = [[University of Connecticut|Connecticut Huskies]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]) 1953–2002 | seating_capacity = 16,200 | }} '''Memorial Stadium''' was a stadium in [[Storrs, Connecticut]]. It was primarily used for [[American football]], and was the home field of the [[University of Connecticut]] [[Connecticut Huskies football|football team]] between 1953 and 2002. The team's current home is [[Pratt & Whitney Stadium at Rentschler Field|Rentschler Field]] in East Hartford. It was built for UConn's move up to D-1A (FBS) in football. The stadium held 16,200 people and was built in 1953. It was demolished{{cite web|title=Demolition Of Memorial Stadium Begins|url=http://www.uconnhuskies.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/052212aab.html}} in May 2012 to make way for a new $40 million basketball practice facility, the UConn Basketball Champions Center,{{cite web|title=Uconn Basketball Champions Center|url=http://www.uconnhuskies.com/sports/m-baskbl/spec-rel/101714aaa.html}} which opened in 2014. ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{s-start-collapsible|header={{s-sta|et}}}} {{succession box | title = Host of the [[NCAA Division I Men's Soccer Championship|College Cup]] | years = 1959 | before = First Stadium | after = [[Brooklyn College Field]] }} {{end}} {{Connecticut Huskies football navbox}} {{University of Connecticut}} [[Category:Defunct college football venues]] [[Category:American football venues in Connecticut]] [[Category:Connecticut Huskies football venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in Tolland County, Connecticut]] [[Category:Connecticut Huskies soccer]] [[Category:Defunct sports venues in Connecticut]] [[Category:Demolished sports venues in Connecticut]] [[Category:1953 establishments in Connecticut]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1953]] [[Category:2012 disestablishments in Connecticut]] [[Category:Sports venues demolished in 2012]] [[Category:Soccer venues in Connecticut]] [[Category:Defunct soccer venues in the United States]] {{Connecticut-stadium-stub}}

[[Image:HomeofHorseracing.jpg|thumb|Part of Palace House in Newmarket, Suffolk, UK]] [[File:The Queen arrives to unveil her Statue at Birdcage Walk, Newmarket, Suffolk.jpg|thumb|The Queen officially opened Palace House in 2016]] '''Palace House''' is the home of Great Britain’s National Heritage Centre of Horseracing and Sporting Art in the remaining part of [[Charles II of England|Charles II]]'s racing palace in [[Newmarket, Suffolk]], England. It is home to the '''National Horseracing Museum''', the '''British Sporting Art Trust''' and [[Retraining of Racehorses]], and was opened by [[Elizabeth II]] in 2016.
==National Horseracing Museum== The National Horseracing Museum of the United Kingdom, a [[Charitable organization|registered charity]],<ref>{{EW charity|283656|THE NATIONAL HORSERACING MUSEUM}}</ref> tells the story of horse racing from its earliest origins to the world-wide phenomenon it is today. This is explored through works of art, silver, bronzes and artifacts including silks worn by famous jockeys such as Lester Piggott and Frankie Dettori. Using the latest interactive and audio-visual displays, the museum also takes a different look at the sport, examining the physical attributes of the elite equine athlete and the importance of thoroughbred pedigree.
It contains collections and records of people and horses involved in the sport of [[horse racing]] from its [[Monarchy|royal]] origins to the present day. Exhibits include the history of horse racing, horse racing in Britain, trophies, paintings of famous horses, trainers and jockeys, jockey uniforms, betting, and horse racing memorabilia. The '''Vestey Gallery of British Sporting Art''' is located in the museum, and features changing exhibits of art relating to sports, including [[hunting]], [[shooting]], fishing, [[boxing]], [[archery]], [[Rowing (sport)|rowing]] and horse racing.
==The British Sporting Art Trust==
The British Sporting Art Trust, a registered charity,<ref>{{EW charity|274156|THE BRITISH SPORTING ART TRUST}}</ref> hosts a large collection of important pieces of British sporting art at Palace House. In the remaining part of Charles II’s racing palace is the Fred Packard Museum and Galleries of British Sporting Art and a new home for the British Sporting Art Trust. Paintings by [[George Stubbs]] and [[Sir Alfred Munnings]] rub shoulders with works from [[John Singer Sargent]] and [[John Wootton]], showcasing some of the finest examples of British Sporting Art.
The gallery explores the development of popular sporting images through paintings, sculpture, print-making and the applied arts. Significant loans have come from the [[Tate Museum|Tate]] and the [[Victoria & Albert Museum]], along with a number of private and public art collections.
==Retraining of Racehorses==
Retraining of Racehorses hosts a number of retired racehorses in the '''Rothschild Yard''' in the Palace House grounds to meet with members of the public.
==List of horses== The National Horseracing Museum contains an extensive archive of images from glass negatives with accompanying biographies. Miller|Miller Sports & Entertainment]] | architect = FFKR Architecture{{cite web|url=http://www.ffkr.com/gallery/energy-solutions-arena-formerly-delta-center/|title=Energy Solutions Arena (formerly the Delta Center)|website=ffkr.com|publisher=FFKR Architecture|accessdate=March 19, 2016}} | structural engineer = Ralph L. Wadsworth Engineering | services engineer = Olsen & Peterson Consulting Engineers, Inc.{{cite web|url=http://utahashrae.org/wp-content/uploads/pastpres/Clark%20Peterson%20bio.pdf|title=Wayne Clark Peterson, P.E.|website=utahshrae.org|publisher=[[ASHRAE]], Utah Chapter|format=PDF|accessdate=March 19, 2016}} | general_contractor = [[Obayashi Corporation|Ohbayashi]]/Sahara | tenants = [[Utah Jazz]] {{small|([[National Basketball Association|NBA]]) (1991–present)}}

{{small|(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|93000000|1990}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}})}} | former_names = Delta Center {{small|(1991–2006)}}
Salt Lake Ice Center {{small|([[2002 Winter Olympics|2002]])}}
EnergySolutions Arena {{small|(2006–15)}} | seating_capacity = 18,300{{cite web|url=http://www.americanradiohistory.com/hd2/IDX-Business/Music/Archive-Billboard-IDX/IDX/90s/1992/Billboard-1992-11-14-OCR-Page-0017.pdf|title=Delta Center|publisher=|accessdate=April 8, 2018}}
7,000 {{small|(Nu Skin Theatre)}} }} '''Vivint Smart Home Arena''' is an [[list of indoor arenas|indoor arena]] located in [[Salt Lake City|Salt Lake City, Utah]]. The building is owned by the [[Gail Miller (businesswoman)|Miller Family]] [[trust law|Legacy Trust]]. The arena is the home of the [[Utah Jazz]] of the [[National Basketball Association]] (NBA) and has been the home venue for other professional athletic teams such as the [[Utah Blaze]] of the [[Arena Football League]] and the [[Utah Starzz]] of the [[Women's National Basketball Association]] (WNBA). It seats 18,306 for basketball, has 56 [[luxury suites]], and 668 [[club seating|club seats]]. Opened in 1991, the arena was known as the '''Delta Center''', under a [[naming rights]] deal with [[Delta Air Lines]], which has a hub at [[Salt Lake City International Airport]]. Salt Lake City-based [[EnergySolutions]] purchased the naming rights in November 2006, after Delta decided not to renew their 15-year contract due to filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy the year prior. From 2006 to 2015 it was known as '''EnergySolutions Arena'''.{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/jazz/energysolutions-arena|title=EnergySolutions Arena|website=nba.com|publisher=[[Utah Jazz]]|date=November 20, 2006|accessdate=March 19, 2016}}{{cite news|url=http://www.ksl.com/?nid=148&sid=661171|title=Delta Center Renamed EnergySolutions Arena|last1=Anderton|first1=Dave|last2=Osterloh|first2=Shelly|work=[[KSL-TV|ksl.com]]|publisher=[[Deseret Digital Media]]|location=Salt Lake City|date=November 20, 2006|accessdate=March 19, 2016}} On October 26, 2015, the arena was renamed as part of a 10-year naming rights contract with the [[Provo, Utah]]-based home security system provider [[Vivint]].{{cite news|last=Lea|first=Bill|title=LHM Sports & Entertainment Introduces Vivint Smart Home Arena for the Utah Jazz|url=http://www.nba.com/jazz/news/lhm-sports-entertainment-introduces-vivint-smart-home-arena-utah-jazz|website=UtahJazz.com|publisher=Utah Jazz|date=October 26, 2015|accessdate=March 30, 2016}} The arena was also home to the [[Figure skating at the 2002 Winter Olympics|figure skating]] and [[Short track speed skating at the 2002 Winter Olympics|short track speed skating]] competitions of the [[2002 Winter Olympics]], where it was referred to as the '''Salt Lake Ice Center'''. ==History== [[File:Energy Solutions Arena.JPG|thumb|left|200px|Interior arena bowl, 2006.]] The arena was originally imagined as 20,000-seat home for the [[Utah Jazz]] and [[Salt Lake Golden Eagles]] to replace the since-demolished arena of the [[Salt Palace (arena)|Salt Palace]], which had 12,616 seats.{{cite news|title=Will Delta Center Pack in the Fans? Ticket Sales Say Yes|last=Hemphill|first=Lex|newspaper=[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]|location=Salt Lake City|page=A6|date=September 29, 1991}} Under the leadership and private financing of Utah businessman [[Larry H. Miller]], ground was broken on May 22, 1990, and it was completed on October 4, 1991 in time for late-October basketball games, at a cost of $93 million (${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|93000000|1991}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars.){{cite news |title=Truss Erection System Scores at Utah Arena|first=Richard|last=Sandomir|publisher=[[Engineering News-Record]] vol. 226|date=October 21, 1991|page=16}}{{inflation-fn|US}} The first game played in the arena was a Golden Eagles match against the [[Peoria Rivermen (IHL)|Peoria Rivermen]] on October 16, 1991, which the home team lost 4–2.{{cite news|title=Eagles Disappoint|last=Kragthorpe|first=Kurt|newspaper=[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]|location=Salt Lake City|page=C1|date=October 17, 1991}} The Eagles had also played the inaugural game in the [[Salt Palace (arena)|Salt Palace arena]] when it opened on October 10, 1969.{{cite news|title=Golden Eagles Jazz up Delta Center|last=Rosetta|first=Dick|newspaper=[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]|location=Salt Lake City|page=C1|date=October 17, 1991}} The Eagles, which were purchased by Miller in 1990, lost nearly a million dollars annually and would not long play in the Delta Center. The first basketball game played in the arena was a Jazz pre-season loss against [[Patrick Ewing]] and the [[New York Knicks]], 101–95.{{cite news|title=Knicks Win to Spoil Jazz Debut|last=Luhm|first=Steve|newspaper=[[Salt Lake Tribune]]location=Salt Lake City|page=D1|date=October 24, 1991}} [[Image:Delta-center.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Exterior view of arena under original name, 2005]] The 1993–95 [[Western Athletic Conference]] men's basketball tournaments were held at the facility, as was the [[1993 NBA All-Star Game]]. The Delta Center also hosted games of the [[1997 NBA Finals|1997]] and [[1998 NBA Finals]] between the Jazz and [[Chicago Bulls]]. In addition to the Utah Jazz and Blaze, the arena has also been the home of the [[Women's National Basketball Association|WNBA]]'s [[Utah Starzz]] from 1997 to 2002, the [[Salt Lake Golden Eagles]] from 1991 to 1994, and the [[Utah Grizzlies (1995–2005)|Utah Grizzlies]] from 1995 to 1997, both of the [[International Hockey League (1945–2001)|International Hockey League]]. Notably, on June 8, 1996, the Delta Center hosted what was then the largest crowd in the history of American minor league hockey: 17,381 fans attended Game 4 of the 1996 [[Turner Cup]] Finals.{{cite news|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1996-06-09/sports/9606090196_1_orlando-solar-solar-bears-utah-grizzlies|title=Orlando Ousted in OT|last=Turner|first=Tim|newspaper=[[Orlando Sentinel]]|date=June 9, 1996|accessdate=March 19, 2016}} The Grizzlies won 3–2 in overtime, completing a four-game sweep of the [[Orlando Solar Bears (IHL)|Orlando Solar Bears]] and earning the IHL championship in their first season in Utah. [[Dan Roberts (announcer)|Dan Roberts]] serves as the official Vivint Smart Home Arena [[public address]] voice for the Jazz. He has been the Jazz's home game announcer since before the arena was built.{{cite news|title=Palace Earsplitting But Not Deafening|last=Fricks|first=Patti T.|newspaper=[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]|page=A1|date=May 11, 1991}} ===Upgrades and renovations=== {{Update|date=February 2018}} [[File:Energy solutions arena.jpg|thumb|right|200px|The exterior of the arena (then known as EnergySolutions Arena) in 2009.]] In 2002, the arena upgraded its super system with ribbon display technology and auxiliary scoreboards from [[Brookings, South Dakota]]-based [[Daktronics]]. During the summer of 2010, the Arena was remodeled, which included the installation of Bear's Backyard, a playground for kids, a new dining area for adults and over 500 television screens. On June 17, 2013 the Utah Jazz announced that the arena would receive a new scoreboard and ribbon display technology, including display screens in each corner of the arena. The new scoreboard and display systems were installed during the 2013 NBA off-season. On September 21, 2016, the Utah Jazz announced plans to renovate and upgrade Vivint Smart Home Arena. The majority of the construction related to the building's renovation, which is estimated to cost US$125 million, will begin at the conclusion of the [[2016–17 Utah Jazz season|2016–17 Utah Jazz basketball season]], with anticipated completion of the renovation by fall 2017.{{cite news|title=$125 Million Arena Transformation to Begin|url=http://www.nba.com/jazz/125-million-arena-transformation-begin|publisher=Utah Jazz|date=September 21, 2016|accessdate=September 21, 2016}} ===Renaming=== [[File:EnergySolution Arena logo.svg|thumb|150px|left|EnergySolutions Arena logo, 2006–2015]] During the [[2002 Winter Olympics|Salt Lake City Olympics]], due to [[International Olympic Committee|IOC]] policies about having corporate sponsorship for venues, the arena was referred to as the '''Salt Lake Ice Center''' during events. After [[Delta Air Lines]] declined to renew their 15-year naming rights contract, which expired on September 30, 2006, the stadium's owner, Larry H. Miller, opted to sell naming rights to [[EnergySolutions]], a [[Low-level waste|low-level nuclear waste]] disposal company headquartered in Salt Lake City.{{cite news|url=http://archive.sltrib.com/story.php?ref=/ci_4694165|title=Delta Center's Out, EnergySolutions Arena Is In|newspaper=[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]|date=November 20, 2006|accessdate=March 19, 2016}}{{cite news|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/650208779/EnergySolutions-Arena-Its-a-mouthful.html|title=Marjorie Cortez: EnergySolutions Arena? It's a mouthful|last=Cortez|first=Marjorie|newspaper=[[Deseret News]]|location=Salt Lake City|date=November 21, 2006|accessdate=March 19, 2016}} The new name was unveiled November 20, prior to the Jazz home game against the [[Toronto Raptors]]. Two stickers were placed on the court, covering up the arena's old name with the new one.{{cite news |url=http://torontosun.ca/Sports/Basketball/2006/11/21/pf-2432303.html |title=Utah Understands Hoffa |last=Koreen|first=Mike|newspaper=[[The Toronto Sun]]|date=November 21, 2006|subscription=yes}} The temporary logos were replaced with official logos on the court sometime in December. EnergySolutions naming rights were set to expire in 2016.{{cite web |url=http://www.leg.wa.gov/JointCommittees/LFOKC/Documents/2008-10-01BasketBall.pdf |title=Sports Facilities Reports |website=leg.wa.gov |publisher=[[Washington State Legislature]] |page=20 |format=PDF |accessdate=March 19, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130616162733/http://www.leg.wa.gov/JointCommittees/LFOKC/Documents/2008-10-01BasketBall.pdf |archive-date=June 16, 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} Initial fan reactions to the new name were predominantly negative. Early nicknames for the arena included "the Dump", a jab at EnergySolutions' radioactive and hazardous waste disposal operations.{{cite news |url=http://archive.sltrib.com/story.php?ref=/ci_4698067 |title=Arena's new name a winner, Miller says |last=Gorrell |first=Mike |newspaper=[[The Salt Lake Tribune]] |date=November 21, 2006 |accessdate=March 19, 2016}} Other suggestions included the Glow Dome, Radium Stadium, Isotope, Chernobowl, Jazzmat, Big Bang, Tox Box, Power House, Hot Spot, Plutonium Palace, Fallout Shelter, Melta Center, and Energy Pollutions Arena.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/11/29/sports/basketball/29stadium.html?_r=0|title=In Utah, the Half-Life of Arena Naming Rights|last=Sandomir|first=Richard|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=November 29, 2006|accessdate=March 19, 2016}} On October 26, 2015, the naming rights were acquired by the locally based home security and automation provider [[Vivint]] in a 10-year contract.{{cite web |url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20151026005788/en/LHM-Sports-Entertainment-Introduces-Vivint-Smart-Home |title=LHM Sports & Entertainment Introduces Vivint Smart Home Arena for the Utah Jazz: Vivint signs multi-year naming rights agreement for downtown facility |website=businesswire.com |publisher=[[Berkshire Hathaway]] |location=San Francisco |date=October 26, 2015 |accessdate=March 19, 2016}} ===John Stockton and Karl Malone statues=== Outside the arena are statues of two players widely regarded as the greatest in the history of the Jazz, as well as among the greatest players in NBA history. The [[John Stockton]] statue was unveiled on March 30, 2005. The [[Karl Malone]] statue was unveiled on March 23, 2006. The Jazz played games on each of those nights but lost both games. ===Larry H. Miller Court=== {| class="wikitable" style="width:250px; float:right; margin:25px 0 25px 25px;" ! colspan="2" style="background: #ffa601;"|Sporting Events Capacity |- |align="left"|Basketball |align="right"|19,911 {{small|(1991–2017)}}
18,306 {{small|(2017–present)}}{{cite web|url=http://www.sltrib.com/sports/jazz/2017/09/26/utah-jazz-officially-christen-renovated-vivint-smart-home-arena/|title=Open for business: Utah Jazz officially christen renovated Vivint Smart Home Arena|work=The Salt Lake Tribune |publisher=|accessdate=April 8, 2018}} |- |align="left"|Ice hockey |align="right"|14,000 |- |align="left"|Dirt shows |align="right"|15,000 |- |align="left"|Professional wrestling |align="right"|12,000-19,387 |- |} On April 15, 2010, over a year after the death of Jazz owner Larry H. Miller, the Jazz [[basketball court]] was named in his honor.{{cite news|title=Jazz honor late owner Miller, rename home floor|url=http://www.nba.com/2010/news/04/15/jazz.miller.ap/index.html|agency=Associated Press|publisher=National Basketball Association|website=NBA.com|date=April 15, 2010|accessdate=March 19, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160504125408/http://www.nba.com/2010/news/04/15/jazz.miller.ap/index.html|archive-date=May 4, 2016|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} With the announcement of the arena's new name on October 26, 2015, the new official name of the court is '''Larry H. Miller Court at Vivint Smart Home Arena'''. ==Notable events== ===Other sports=== The facility played host to the 1999 [[U.S. Figure Skating Championships]]. The arena was also home to the [[Figure skating at the 2002 Winter Olympics|figure skating]] and [[Short track speed skating at the 2002 Winter Olympics|short track speed skating]] competitions of the [[2002 Winter Olympics]].{{cite report |url=http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/2002/2002v1.pdf|title=Official Report of the XIX Olympic Winter Games |publisher=Salt Lake Olympic Committee|volume=1|pages=93–4|format=PDF|isbn=0-9717961-0-6|accessdate=March 19, 2016}} In the final of the [[Short track speed skating at the 2002 Winter Olympics – Men's 1000 metres|Men's 1000 metres]] Short track speed skating event at the 2002 Winter Olympics, veteran Australian [[Steven Bradbury]] became the most unlikely winner in Winter Olympic history when he won the race after [[Apolo Anton Ohno]] (USA), [[Mathieu Turcotte]] (Canada), [[Ahn Hyun-Soo]] ([[South Korea]]), and [[Li Jiajun]] (China) all fell on the final turn and left Bradbury, who was running last and about {{convert|15|m|ft}} behind the pack, to come through and claim Australia's first ever Winter Olympics Gold Medal. Vivint Smart Home Arena was the site of the West regional semifinals ("[[NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament#Regional semifinals and finals|Sweet Sixteen]]") and championship ("[[Elite Eight]]") in the [[2010 NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament]]. The venue also hosted first and second-round games in the [[2013 NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament|2013]] and [[2017 NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament|2017]] editions of the tournament, and it will do so again in [[2019 NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament|2019]]. ===Concerts=== In addition to sports, the arena was intended to host large music concerts. Social House || [[Sweetener World Tour]] || — || — || |} ===In film=== The movie ''[[Legally Blonde 2: Red, White & Blonde]]'' was partially filmed in the arena. ==Tornado== The arena's roof was damaged by severe winds associated with the [[Salt Lake City Tornado]] of August 11, 1999, costing $3,757,000 (equivalent to ${{Inflation|US|3757000|1999|fmt=C}} in {{Inflation-year|US}}) to repair.{{cite news|title=A Real Twister: 1 Year Later: A Whirlwind of Memories; Salt Lake City Recalls Devastating Tornado that Changed Lives Forever|last=Woolf|first=Jim|newspaper=[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]|location=Salt Lake City|page=|date=August 10, 2000}} ==Awards and recognitions== Vivint Smart Home Arena is well known for being one of the hardest places to play for visiting teams in the NBA. According to an NBA Players Poll taken by ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' on February 11, 2008, the Vivint Arena is considered "the most intimidating arena in the NBA" with 20% of the vote made up of 240 current NBA players.{{cite news |title=Si Players Nba Poll |url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1109385/index.htm |work=[[Sports Illustrated]] |date=February 11, 2008 |accessdate=March 19, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130326192626/http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1109385/index.htm|archivedate=March 26, 2013|via=[[Internet Archive|web.archive.org]]}} Many commentators referred to the arena as the "Decibel Center", a play on the name "Delta Center". During Game 5 of the [[1997 NBA Finals]], a decibel meter installed at floor level had readings of over 110 decibels, close to the noise generated by a jet takeoff. Also, during the [[1997 NBA Finals]], [[NBA on NBC|NBC's]] [[Hannah Storm]] called the then-named Delta Center "one of the loudest places in sports".{{youtube|id=1vWHDxG0YLk|title=NBA on NBC Intro - 1997...}} {{dead link|date=March 2016}} ==References== {{reflist|22em}} ==External links== {{commons category|Vivint Smart Home Arena}} * {{official website|http://www.vivintarena.com}} {{s-start-collapsible|header={{s-sta|et}}}} {{succession box | title = Home of the
